channel.title: Ubuntu executables (ubuntu)
channel.description:
ok, I have an executable .sh file with the following in it:
sudo rmdir /opt/lampp/htdocs sudo mv /home/david/htdocs /opt/lampp/htdocs
now, this only works if I right click >> run in terminal, then enter my password. Is there any way I can enter my password in the .sh file so it I wont have to run in terminal and enter my password??

If you set it for 1440 minutes (24 hours) then it should only prompt you once a day or if you log off.

Except that a new terminal window is a new session, unless it’s set up incorrectly. (No idea on Ubuntu default)
[/quote]The variable applies to all sessions, as far as I know.

What I mean by that, is each new terminal session reads the current timer, it does not create a new one.[/quote]

item.title: Ubuntu executables (ubuntu)
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

By default, the password is stored for 15 minutes. If you want to go about disabling it, try this:

Use the command visudo to modify the /etc/sudoers files. Find the line:

%admin  ALL=(ALL) ALL

And change it to:

%admin  ALL=NOPASSWORD: ALL

However, I don’t recommend it.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 22, 2008, 04:55:25 pm[/size][hr]You can also change the timestamp_timeout in the /etc/sudoers file to a higher value. This means that it will take longer for you to have to re-enter your password. If you set it for 1440 minutes (24 hours) then it should only prompt you once a day or if you log off.
